The goverment is also to blame. They are not doing enought to stop the distruction of the enviorment. They are too busy making deals with big buisnesses to care about the enviorment. They are more concered about making money than saving the planet.

However, there is still hope. If we all work together, we can stop the distruction of the enviorment. We can make a change. We can start by reducing, reusing, and recycling. We can start by using public transport and carpooling. We can start by buying sustainable products.

Many companys are already making a change. They are using sustainable materials, reducing waste, and reducing their carbon footprint. They are showing us that it is posible to make a profit and still care about the enviorment.

In conclusion, consumerism is a curse on the enviorment. It is a major contributer to the distruction of our planet. But it is not too late. We can still make a change. We can still save the enviorment.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: Technology has alienated people instead of bringing them together. Discuss.
text:
Technology has alienated people instead of bringing them together, or has it? With the rise of technology, people has become more isolated then ever before. They spend most of their time staring at screens, tapping away on their phones, and neglecting the people around them. This trend has only escalated with the advent of social media, where people can curate a perfect online persona, and hide behind a mask of superficiality.

Some people argue that technology has made it easier for people to connect with each other, but I believe that this is just a myth. For instance, in Japan, there exist groups of individuals, labelled as 'otakus', who devote their entire lives to the digital world and therefore experience extreme fear, anxiety, or detachment when forced to interact within the real world. This shows that technology is actually detrimental towards the construction of lasting and meaningful human relationships, by damaging the individual's ability to connect with others socially.

However, some people would disagree with me, they would say that technology has improved the way we communicate with each other. For example, video conferencing allows people to connect with others from all over the world, and social media allows us to keep in touch with our friends and family who are far away. But I think this is just a superficial way of connecting with others, it's not a real connection.

Moreover, technology has also made us more lazy, we don't even bother to get out of our houses to meet our friends, we just send them a text or a snapchat. We don't even bother to learn about what's going on in the world, we just scroll through our social media feeds and think we're informed. This is not a healthy way of living, and it's all because of technology.

In conclusion, technology has definitely alienated people, it has made us more isolated, more lazy, and more superficial. We need to be careful about how we use technology, and make sure it's not controlling our lives.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: To lodge all power in one party and keep it there is to ensure bad government. Do you agree?
text:
To lodge all power in one party and keep it there is to ensure bad government. Do you agree?

In today's world, it is a common debate wheather a single party should hold all the power in a country. Some people belive that it is a good idea because it will lead to efficent decision making and there will be no need to waste time on debate and arguement. However, I strongly disagree with this view. In my opnion, giving all the power to one party is a recipie for disaster.

Firstly, when one party has all the power, it can lead to corruption and abuse of power. This is because there is no one to check on them and make sure they are doing the right thing. For example, in some african countries, the ruling party has been in power for decades and has become very corrupt. They use the country's resourses for their own benifit and neglect the needs of the people.

Secondly, when one party has all the power, it can lead to bad decision making. This is because there is no one to provide alternative views and ideas. For example, in china, the government made a policy to limit the number of children a family can have. This policy was a disaster and led to many social and economic problems. If there was another party to provide alternative views, maybe this policy would not have been implemented.

Thirdly, when one party has all the power, it can lead to lack of representation of minority groups. This is because the ruling party only cares about the interests of their own supporters and neglect the needs of other groups. For example, in some countries, the ruling party is dominated by one ethnic group and they neglect the needs of other ethnic groups.

In conclusion, giving all the power to one party is a bad idea. It can lead to corruption, bad decision making and lack of representation of minority groups. Therefore, I strongly agree that to lodge all power in one party and keep it there is to ensure bad government.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: Can the media ever tell the truth?
text:
Can the Media Ever Tell the Truth?

The media has been a vital part of our lifes for a long time. It has the power to shape our mindsets and perceptions. However, there is a growing concern about the truthfulness of the media. Some people believe that the media never tell the truth, while others think that it can be a powerful tool for empowerment. In my opinion, the media can tell the truth, but it is not always the case.

One of the main reasons why people doubt the media is because of its subjective nature. The media is not just about reporting facts, it also involves analysis and interpretation of information. This means that the media is prone to human bias, which can lead to inaccurate reporting. For example, the same event can be reported differently by different news channels, depending on their political leanings. This can be misleading and can create confusion among the public.

Another reason why people question the media's credibility is because of its commercial nature. The media is a business, and like any business, it is driven by profit. This means that the media can be selective in the information it reports, and may prioritize sensationalism over accuracy. This can lead to the misrepresentation of facts and the spread of false information.

However, despite these flaws, I believe that the media can still tell the truth. There are many instances where the media has played a crucial role in exposing injustices and bringing about positive change. For example, investigative journalism has been instrumental in uncovering corruption and abuse of power. The media has also given a voice to marginalized communities and has helped to bring about social change.

The rise of new media has also changed the way we consume information. With the internet and social media, we have access to a wide range of sources of information. This has made it easier for us to verify the accuracy of information and to make informed decisions. New media has also given people the power to express themselves and to share their stories, which has helped to promote diversity and inclusivity.

In conclusion, while the media is not perfect, I believe that it can tell the truth. The media has the power to shape our perceptions and to bring about positive change. However, it is up to us to be critical consumers of information and to verify the accuracy of what we read and see.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: Can national nuclear programmes ever be justified?
text:
Can national nuclear programmes ever be justified? In todays world, this question is more relevent then ever. With the threat of nuclear war looming over our heads, it is a wonder that any country would even consider having a nuclear programme. However, I beleive that national nuclear programmes can be justified in certain circumstances.

Firstly, national nuclear programmes can serve as a deterent to other countries. If a country has nuclear capabilites, other countries are less likely to attack them. This is because they know that the country they are attacking has the power to retaliate with devastating consequences. For example, during the cold war, the threat of mutually assured destruction prevented the US and the Soviet Union from engaging in full-scale war. This is a clear example of how national nuclear programmes can be justified in terms of national security.

Another reason why national nuclear programmes can be justified is that they can provide a sustainable source of energy. With the worlds fossil fuels depleting at an alarming rate, nuclear energy is becoming an increasingly attractive option. Nuclear energy is clean and does not produce any greenhouse gases, making it a much more enviromentally friendly option compared to fossil fuels. In addition, nuclear energy can provide a significant portion of a countrys energy needs. For example, in Japan, nuclear energy accounted for nearly 30% of the countrys energy needs before the Fukushima disaster.

However, there are also many drawbacks to national nuclear programmes. One of the main concerns is the risk of nuclear accidents. Accidents such as Chernobyl and Fukushima have shown us the devastating consequences of a nuclear meltdown. These accidents can have long-term effects on the enviroment and human health. Furthermore, the storage of nuclear waste is also a major concern. Nuclear waste remains radioactive for thousands of years, and there is currently no safe way to dispose of it.

In conclusion, national nuclear programmes can be justified in certain circumstances. While there are many risks associated with nuclear programmes, the benefits of increased national security and a sustainable source of energy cannot be ignored. However, it is crucial that these programmes are regulated and monitored closely to prevent accidents and minimize the risks.

author: Skyler
title: ‘Prosperity is all that matters; everything else can take a back seat.’ Do you agree?
text:
Prosperity is all that matters; everything else can take a back seat. Some people say that this is wrong, but I think they just don't understand how important money is. If you have lots of money, you can do anything! You can buy the best food, clothes, and houses. You can travel to amazing places and meet interesting people.  You can even help others less fortunate. So why wouldn't you want to be rich?

Sure, there are some things that are important besides money, like family and friends. But at the end of the day, money makes everything easier. Without money, you're stuck. You can't get a good job, you can't afford healthcare, and you can't even put food on the table.  

Think about it: all those famous people, they are rich because they are successful. They have achieved something great, and their wealth is a reward for their hard work. It's not just about being greedy; it's about being the best and having the resources to make a real difference in the world. If everyone was poor, nothing would ever get done! 

Some people say that rich people don't care about other people. But that's just not true. Many wealthy individuals donate large sums of money to charities and support important causes. They use their wealth to make the world a better place.

So yes, prosperity is all that matters. It's the key to success, happiness, and making a positive impact on the world. If you want to be truly happy and fulfilled, then you need to strive for wealth and achieve your dreams.

author: Skyler
title: Do you agree that freedom of speech should never be denied even though it can be abused?
text:
Freedom of speech is really important, like, super duper important.  Everyone should be able to say what they think, right? But sometimes people use their words to hurt other people. Like, imagine if your friend said something mean about you to everyone. That would make you feel bad, wouldn't it?

Some people say that we should never stop anyone from talking, even if what they say is wrong. They say that it's important for people to be able to express themselves freely. But I think it's also important to protect people from being hurt. 

For example, imagine someone spreading rumors about another person online. That could really damage that person's reputation and make their life miserable. Or what if someone uses their words to incite violence? That could lead to real harm and danger.

I think it's important to find a balance between freedom of speech and protecting people from harm. We need to be able to speak our minds, but we also need to be responsible for the words we choose. 

Sometimes, it might be necessary to limit someone's freedom of speech if they are using it to hurt others. It's like when you break a rule at school – sometimes you have to get in trouble so that everyone can stay safe and happy.

author: Skyler
title: ‘When children grow up exposed to violence, the world will pay the price.” Discuss.
text:
When children grow up around violence, the world get's hurt bad. Like, really bad.  Violence is everywhere you look, from the news to your neighbor down the street. It can be physical, emotional, or even mental, which is super messed up.

Kids are supposed to be playing and learning, not dealing with this stuff. They are trying to figure out who they are and how to be good people, but violence messes everything up. When kids see violence all the time, it becomes normal to them. They think that's just how the world works. That's scary, right?

Imagine a kid growing up in a war zone. They see bombs exploding, people getting hurt, and families being torn apart. What do you think that does to their brain?  It makes them scared, angry, and confused. 

They might start acting out themselves, because that's all they know. It's like a broken record playing over and over again: violence leads to more violence. This stuff doesn't just stay in one place either. It spreads like a disease.

Think about the people who commit acts of terrorism. They were probably exposed to violence when they were kids. Maybe they saw their parents fight, or maybe they lived in a dangerous neighborhood. Whatever it was, violence shaped them into the people they are today. 


That's why it's so important to teach kids about peace and non-violence. We need to show them that there are other ways to solve problems, besides using force. We need to create a world where kids can grow up safe and happy, without having to worry about violence.  Otherwise, the world is going to keep hurting itself, and nobody wins in the end.

author: Junwei
title: A government that fails to win the trust of the people is doomed to fail. Comment
text:
A government that can't win the trust of its people is doomed to fail. That's just common sense right? I mean, if people don't believe their leaders are honest or care about them, they won't listen to what they say or follow their rules. It's like when your parents tell you to clean your room and you just ignore them because you don't trust them to know why it's important.

But is this really always true? What about governments that seem to stay in power even though people don't like them? Like, what about North Korea? People there probably don't trust their leader at all, but he still runs the country. Or maybe, just maybe, they are brainwashed so much that they actually do trust him! 

It's hard to say for sure because sometimes governments can use sneaky ways to stay in power even if people are unhappy. They might control the news and make it hard for people to speak out against them.  That way, even if people don't trust the government, they don't have a way to get rid of them.

Another thing is that sometimes people just care more about their own political team than they do about whether the leader is trustworthy. Like in the 2019 UK election, Boris Johnson was kind of a jerk but people voted for him anyway because he promised to leave the European Union.  They didn't care if he was honest or not, they just wanted Brexit!

So, maybe it's not as simple as saying that a government that loses trust is doomed to fail. There are lots of other factors at play, like how people feel about different political parties and how easy it is to speak out against the government.

author: Junwei
title: To what extent is the use of violence in today’s world acceptable?
text:
Violence is a really big problem today, and everyone agrees that it's bad.  But sometimes, you just gotta use violence to stop other people from hurting you or your friends. Like, if someone tries to rob you at gunpoint, you have to shoot them back, right? That's self-defense!

There are some times when violence is totally okay though, like when the police need to protect people. If a crazy guy with a knife attacks innocent people, the cops gotta shoot him to save everyone else.  It's sad, but sometimes it's the only way to keep people safe.

Another example is war.  When countries fight each other, they use violence because that's how they settle their differences. It's not always fair or nice, but sometimes violence is necessary. Like when America went to Iraq to get rid of Saddam Hussein, that was a good thing, right? They were fighting for freedom!

But violence isn't always the answer.  Lots of people believe in peace and love, like Gandhi. He said "An eye for an eye leaves the whole world blind," which means that if we keep using violence, it will just lead to more violence. 


That's why we need to try to solve problems peacefully, through talking and understanding each other. Violence should be a last resort, only used when absolutely necessary.

author: Huang Junwei
title: Should everyone be treated equally all the time?
text:
Should everyone be treated equally all the time? That's a big question, right? Like, should we all get the same amount of candy at Halloween, or the same grade on a test even if we did different levels of work?  

On one hand, it seems really fair to treat everyone the same. It's like the golden rule: do unto others as you would have them do unto you. If you want people to be nice to you, you should be nice to them, right? And if you want to get a good grade, you gotta put in the work, no matter who else is in the class.

But then again, sometimes treating everyone the same just doesn't make sense.  Like, imagine if my little brother got the same amount of homework as me. He's still learning how to read! It wouldn't be fair because we both need different levels of help. 

And what about people who are already struggling? They might need more support than someone who's already doing well. Like, think about a kid who doesn't have enough food at home.  He needs extra help, not the same amount as someone who eats three meals a day! 

So maybe treating everyone exactly the same all the time isn't the best idea. Maybe it's more important to treat people fairly, which means giving them what they need, even if that's different from what other people need.

author: J Wang
title: Art is only worth what people will pay for it. Do you agree?
text:
Art is only worth what people pay for it? I mean, that's kinda true but also not really. Like, think about those famous paintings, right? They cost millions! Does that mean they are actually better than, like, my grandma's watercolor painting of a cat? Probably not, but people pay big bucks for 'em.

It's all about supply and demand, I guess. If there's only one Mona Lisa, it's gonna be worth a fortune because everyone wants it. But if there are tons of copies, nobody will pay much for it. Same with music. Pop stars sell millions of albums, so they're worth a lot. But your friend's band who plays in their garage? Probably not so much.

But art isn't just about money, right? Like, sometimes the most meaningful art is free. My sister makes these amazing sculptures out of recycled stuff, and they're totally priceless to me even though nobody's paying for them. It's all about how it makes you feel, ya know?

So, yeah, people pay a lot for some art, but that doesn't mean it's automatically better. And there's tons of amazing art out there that's totally free and just as valuable. Don't let the money fool ya!

author: Ho
title: ‘Education is a solution to social inequality.’ Do you agree?
text:
Education is a big deal, everyone says so. Like, it's supposed to be the way up for everyone, no matter where you come from. You start at the same point and then how hard you work decides your future. That's what they tell us anyway. But in reality, it's not that simple. Education is more like a game rigged against some people. 

See, rich kids already have an advantage. Their parents can pay for all sorts of extra stuff, like fancy tutoring and camps and trips.  It's like they get a head start before the race even begins. It doesn't matter how smart you are if you don't have the money to help you learn. I mean, think about it, my friend Sarah's dad takes her to Italy every summer! She learns about history and art firsthand. My family goes to Walmart for vacation.

And then there's the whole culture thing. Rich kids are exposed to more stuff, like museums and books and plays.  They learn how to talk properly and write good essays. It's not fair because poor kids might not have those same opportunities. 

Even schools aren't always equal. Some schools have better teachers, better resources, and better everything. So even if you work hard, you might still be stuck in a bad school that doesn't give you the tools to succeed.  It's like saying everyone can win the Olympics but some people are given gold medals already!

So yeah, education is important, but it's not a magic solution. It's just another way that rich people stay on top and poor people struggle. We need to fix the system so everyone has a real chance. Otherwise, it's just a big lie.

author: Ho Ting H
title: Assess the view that not enough consideration is given to the green agenda.
text:
The green agenda, it's something that everyone talks about but nobody really does anything about. It's like we all pretend to care about saving the planet while secretly enjoying our disposable plastic straws and fast fashion. This is a problem because the earth needs serious help, and our lack of action is only going to make things worse.

Governments say they care about the environment, but their actions tell a different story. They sign international agreements like the Paris Climate Agreement, which sounds really good on paper, but then they go back to polluting the air and water. For example, some countries are still building coal-fired power plants even though we know they are harmful to the climate. It's like they're just trying to look good without actually doing anything meaningful.

Companies also claim to be environmentally friendly, but their main goal is always profit. They might use recycled materials in their products or plant a few trees, but they still produce tons of waste and contribute to pollution. It's all just greenwashing to make them look better to consumers.  Think about plastic companies, they make billions selling us things that end up in landfills for centuries! 

And what about individuals? We're the ones who actually use these products and create the demand for them. But many people are too busy with their lives to think about the impact of their choices. They might recycle occasionally or buy a reusable water bottle, but they still rely on fossil fuels for transportation and consume more than they need. It's easy to feel overwhelmed and powerless, but we all have a responsibility to make a difference.


We need to demand more from our governments and corporations. We need to hold them accountable for their environmental impact and push them to make real changes. As individuals, we can also make a difference by reducing our consumption, choosing sustainable products, and speaking out against environmentally harmful practices. The future of the planet depends on it.

author: Ying
title: Does technology always make life better?
text:
Technology make our lives better, right? Like, think about phones. They let you talk to anyone, anywhere. Its super cool for keeping in touch with friends and family, even if they live far away. And now we got all these apps, too! You can play games, watch videos, learn new stuff - it's like having a whole world in your pocket.

Plus, technology makes things easier. Robots do lots of jobs that used to be done by people, which means more time for us to relax and have fun. And online shopping is so convenient! You can buy anything you want, whenever you want, without even leaving your house. 

Sure, there are some bad things about technology too. Like, sometimes people use it to do bad stuff, like hacking into computers or spreading fake news. But that's not really the fault of technology itself, its just how some people choose to use it.  

Overall, I think technology makes life way better. Its changed the world for the good, and I can't wait to see what amazing things it will do next!

author: Ying
title: Do you agree that it is inevitable for the elderly to be a burden to society?
text:
Do Elderly People Really Burdens Society?

Some people think that old people are just a problem for society. They say that they don't work anymore so they cost money and don't help anyone.  But I disagree! Old people are important, even if they can't run as fast or remember things as easy.

First of all, older people have lots of experience. They've seen a lot in their lives and learned from mistakes. They can give good advice to younger people about jobs, relationships, and even just how to live a happy life. Like my grandpa, he always says "Don't spend all your money on video games" and I think he knows what he's talking about!

Second, old people keep families together. They tell stories about the past, teach kids about traditions, and make sure everyone feels connected. Without them, families would be like puzzle pieces that don't fit together. Like my grandma always makes her famous cookies for Christmas, it wouldn't be the same without them!

Some people say that old people use up too much money because they need doctors and medicine. That's true, but think about it: everyone needs healthcare sometime! And besides, old people helped build our society and made it what it is today. Don't you think they deserve to be taken care of?

author: Ying
title: Is modern science and technology always a blessing?
text:
Is modern science and technology always a blessing? In our fast paced society, people think that new science and tech is the answer to everything. We have things like genetic engineering and cloning which are really cool, but some of it makes me nervous. 

I think modern tech can be a curse sometimes because things get outdated so quickly. Remember penicillin? Everyone thought it was going to cure everything! But now bacteria are getting resistant to it, making it useless. This is happening with lots of medicine because science moves fast and germs even faster.  My grandma got really sick from a resistant bacteria and had to go to the hospital for months.

Also, modern tech can cause big problems with morals. Like abortion, some people think it's murder and others think women should choose. Stem cell research is another example, some say it's playing God! All this makes me feel like science is getting ahead of us.

And don't forget about greedy companies who use tech for profit.  Genetically modified rice was supposed to help people but companies made it so farmers had to buy new seeds every year. This led to lots of farmers in India going broke and even committing suicide! It's like technology is being used for the wrong reasons.

Nuclear power is another example, it started out as a way to make electricity cleaner but then we used it to bomb people in World War II. That was horrible!  Even today, countries use nuclear weapons which scares me a lot. 

I guess what I'm saying is that technology can be amazing but it's important to remember the dangers. We need to think carefully about how we use it and make sure it's used for good, not for greed or destruction.

author: Ying
title: ‘Protecting the environment is a futile pursuit.’ How far do you agree?
text:
Protecting the environment is hard, like super hard. Some people say it's a waste of time, that we can't fix it anyway. They say stuff like "the world is on fire" and point to all the pollution and climate change. It's true, things are bad, but I think we can still make a difference.

Think about it, technology is always getting better. We have electric cars now, and solar panels, and even fancy stuff like carbon capture that sucks up all the bad gases. Maybe someday we'll have flying cars powered by clean energy! It's not impossible, right? 

Plus, people are starting to care more about the environment. Kids are protesting, governments are talking about it, and companies are trying to be greener. Greta Thunberg is like a superhero for the planet, making everyone pay attention. If enough people demand change, politicians have to listen. 

It's also not just about one country, it's gotta be everyone working together.  The Paris Agreement was a big step, where countries promised to reduce their pollution. It might take time, but if we all keep pushing, we can make a difference. 

Giving up is easy, but that's not who we are. We're humans, and we're capable of amazing things. Let's use our brains and our hearts to protect the planet for future generations.

author: Ying
title: ‘In this era of rapid Scientific development, religion is becoming obsolete.’ How far do you agree?
text:
Science and religion, they be two big different things, right? Science is all about figuring stuff out with experiments and stuff, like how gravity works or why the sky is blue. Religion is more about believing in God and stuff, and what happens after you die.  Some people think science is making religion less important because we're learning so much about the world.

For example, Darwin said that humans evolved from monkeys, which kinda goes against what some religions teach about how people were created. And now we can do things like make babies in labs, which feels like magic but is actually science! So maybe religion isn't as needed anymore? 

But I think science and religion can actually work together.  Science helps us understand the world around us, and religion helps us understand our place in it. Like, science can tell us how the heart works, but religion can give us comfort when someone we love dies. 

Plus, lots of scientists believe in God! They see science as a way to learn more about God's creations, like a really big puzzle. And some religions even encourage learning about science, because it helps us understand the world better.  So maybe science isn't making religion obsolete after all. Maybe they just work in different ways.

author: Ying
title: Consider the effectiveness of Science and technology in resolving world problems today.
text:
Science and technology are often seen as magic bullets for solving the world's problems. People think that because science has given us things like antibiotics and vaccines, it can solve anything. But I don't think that's true. Science has its limits, and sometimes it even makes things worse.

Take nuclear power, for example. It was invented to solve the problem of energy, but then we used it to make atomic bombs, which killed millions of people in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Even Albert Einstein, who helped develop the theory of relativity, said he regretted his work because it led to such destruction.

Then there's genetically modified crops. They were supposed to help feed the world, but they ended up causing more problems. Some farmers bought these seeds, thinking they would make more money, but they ended up in debt because the seeds didn't work as promised.  Plus, these crops can harm the environment.

Science is also limited by human greed and selfishness. Scientists sometimes focus on making money instead of solving problems. They might fudge their research to get grants or invent products that are harmful. This happened with Hwang Woo Suk, a Korean scientist who faked his stem cell research.

Another problem is that science moves so fast. What works today might be outdated tomorrow. Bacteria are constantly evolving, so we need new antibiotics all the time. It's a race against time. 

In the end, science can be a powerful tool, but it's not perfect. We need to be careful how we use it and make sure that it benefits everyone, not just a few people.

author: Ying
title: ‘Our job as Scientists is to find the truth.’ How far do you agree that this view accurately reflects the role of Scientists today?
text:
Our job as Scientists is to find the truth. This is what everyone thinks, right? Since the scientific revolution, Science has made giant leaps, with Scientist exploring new frontiers and pushing boundaries like never before. Huge advancements in scientific discovery have opened up many possibilities, such as biotechnology, genetic engineering, cloning and more. But what is truly the main role of scientists in the modern world? While some may argue that the main role of scientists is to seek truth, I beg to differ. 

Though it is true that science was originally pursued as an intellectual study to find out more about our world and seek truth, the temptation of our modern world today such as that of fame and monetary gain have adulterated what started off as pure and innocent intentions of scientist to seek truth.  Proponents of the view that scientists today seek to find truth argue that science is the study of the world around us and the cornerstone of scientific discovery is ultimately curiosity. In this respect, the main role of scientists should be to seek truth regarding our world. For example, several scientist today have pumped in millions of dollars simply to find out more about how the earth came to be and how humans came into existence. Another classic example is Albert Einstein, who made groundbreaking discoveries in the world of Physics while working as a clerk at a Swiss office, all on the basis of curiosity. These examples show that the main motivating factor of scientists is curiosity about our world and thus, the pursuit of truth. Even the nature of the scientific inquiry boils down to the fundamental trait of curiosity. As such, the main role of scientists today is to discover the truth.  

However, while the initial intentions of scientists may have been to seek truth, the temptations of the modern world, such as money and profits have caused many scientists to diverge from their original aim of seeking truth to that of profit maximisation. For instance, companies that manufacture genetically modified crops such as Monsanto have engineered their crops to be infertile and also attached patent rights to them, causing them to be sold at exorbitant prices to make more profit. This forced poor subsistent farmers in India to buy a new batch of seeds at the end of every season, causing many of them to be mired in huge debt. Eventually, many of them committed suicide in desperation, contributing to the high number of farmer suicides in India. Another example is thalidomide, which is a sleeping pill manufactured by Scientists which was assumed to be so mild even pregnant women could take the pill and would result in no side effects. Scientist were so eager to market their findings and profit from it that the drug was not properly tested before it was marketed causing thousands of babies to be born with deformed limbs. As such profit maximisation has become a priority that has began to override the pursuit of truth for many scientists, who would do anything just to earn an extra cent. As Albert Einstein once aptly quipped, “It has become appallingly obvious that our technology has exceeded our humanity.” The syphilis experiment conducted in Alabama where blacks were unknowingly injected with syphilis virus to investigate its effects on the human body for scientist to save cost on obtaining willing test subjects also shows the extent the scientist would go just to maximise their profits. Indeed, motives of scientists have taken on a much more insidious nature and has definitely gone beyond that of seeking truth.  

In modern society, many scientists have also prioritised fame over seeking truth. In today’s context, were science is often placed on a pedestal and lauded as the most effective solution to our problems, much fame and recognition is given to scientists who make groundbreaking discoveries. This can lead scientist to focus more on making sensational discoveries that will earn them recognition rather than pursuing less glamorous but equally important research. The problem of malnutrition amongst African children was also reduced by discoveries such as golden rice which is rich in vitamin A. another illustration is Physician Edward Jenner who discovered the vaccine for smallpox but refused to attach patent rights to it as that would prevent the poor from obtaining access to the vaccine. Such scientists have gone beyond the pursuit of cold, hard truths to devoting their discoveries to advancing and improving the lives of the human race. Thus the role of scientists today has stretched beyond that of seeking truth to resolving pressing world problems. 



In conclusion, the role of scientists in the modern world has stretched far beyond that of seeking truth. Intentions of scientists have evolved over time, changing for both the better and the worse. More precaution should be exercised and individuals should be more wary of the myriad of scientific discoveries today. Scientific discoveries may have yet to show itself to lead to the formation of a utopian fantasy, but let us not let it head in the direction of a Faustian nightmare.

author: Ying
title: ‘Science and business should never mix.’ How far do you agree?
text:
Science and business should never mix, that's what I think!  Some people say they gotta work together, but I disagree. When money gets involved, science gets messed up. 

It's supposed to be about helping people, right? But now companies just want to make a profit. They don't care if poor people can't afford medicine or food because it's not profitable enough. Like, remember that golden rice thing? It was supposed to help people with hunger, but the company made it so farmers had to buy new seeds every year! That made things worse for them, and they ended up going broke.  It's like they are trying to make money off of people starving!

And what about all those drugs that cost a fortune? People with HIV in Africa can't even get the medicine because it's too expensive. It's just wrong! Science should be for everyone, not just the rich. 

Plus, when businesses are involved, things get really unethical. They might do dangerous experiments on people to save money or make a quick buck. Remember that thing with the syphilis experiment?  They gave sick people syphilis to see what happened! That's horrible!

So yeah, science and business shouldn't mix. It leads to greed, inequality, and even harm. We need scientists who are passionate about helping people, not just making money.

author: Ying
title: Consider the impact of technology on world hunger today.
text:
Technology and World Hunger

World hunger is a really big problem. Like, millions of people don't have enough to eat every day. It's sad! And technology, it should be able to help, right? 

People are always talking about how genetically modified crops can grow more food, even in bad weather. They say things like "golden rice" has vitamin A and can help kids who are sick. That sounds good, but does it really work?

Sometimes these new plants mess things up. Like, there was this one time they put a gene from Brazil nuts into soybeans, and it made people allergic! And then there's this corn that kills all the bugs, even the good ones. It's like, technology can be helpful, but it can also be dangerous.

Plus, even if we had perfect technology, there are other problems. Corrupt officials steal money meant for helping people, and some countries don't even want foreign aid. So even if we could grow tons of food, it might not get to the people who need it.

And then there are the big companies that make all this technology. They want to make money, so they charge a lot for seeds and stuff. Farmers can't afford it, and they end up in more trouble. It's like, technology is supposed to help, but it just makes things worse for some people.

So what can we do? I think we need to focus on helping farmers directly, teaching them how to grow food sustainably, and making sure that everyone has access to the resources they need. Technology can be a part of the solution, but it's not the only answer.

author: Ying
title: ‘In today’s world, the arts have become irrelevant. ’ How far do you agree?
text:
The arts are dead!  Who needs paintings and music when we have iPhones and computers? That's what my dad always says. In today's world, with all these new technologies, art seems so old-fashioned and unimportant. People are too busy working and making money to care about stuff like that. 

Take Damien Hirst for example. He sold a skull covered in diamonds for millions of dollars! Can you believe it? Who would pay that much for something so ridiculous? It just shows how out of touch the art world is with real people.  People are struggling to pay their bills, while these artists are making a fortune selling overpriced junk.

Some people say that art is important because it helps us understand the world around us. But honestly, can't we just learn about history and science instead? Those things are actually useful. Art is just a waste of time and money.

Besides, with all the amazing things we can do with technology now, who needs art anymore? We have video games, movies, and virtual reality. These things are much more exciting and engaging than staring at a painting or listening to music.

So yeah, I think the arts are pretty irrelevant these days.

author: Ying
title: To what extent is poverty the fault of the individual?
text:
Poverty is a big problem. Like, really big. Everyone knows that people who are poor are poor because they don't work hard enough, right? But is that really true?

It's easy to say that the poor should just get a job and stop being lazy. But think about it: sometimes people are born into poverty. Their parents are poor, so they don't have money for good schools or doctors. They might even live in dangerous neighborhoods where it's hard to find a job. It's not fair to blame someone for being born into a bad situation.

There are some countries that do a good job helping their poor people. Like, Singapore is super rich now because everyone works really hard and nobody gets handouts. But that doesn't mean that all poor people just need to try harder.  Some countries don't even have enough food for their people, let alone fancy welfare programs. And what about corrupt governments who steal the money that should be helping the poor? 

Also, some religions make it hard for women to get an education. This means they can't get good jobs and help their families out of poverty. It's not like women choose to be poor because they want to stay at home all day. Sometimes, they just don't have any other options.

Big companies also contribute to poverty. They pay workers really low wages and sometimes even make them work in dangerous conditions. It's not fair to blame the poor for working these jobs when they need money to survive.

So, is poverty the fault of the individual? Not really. There are so many other factors that play a role, like where you're born, who your parents are, and even what religion you follow. We need to focus on helping people escape poverty instead of blaming them for being poor.

author: Chirin Soh
title: The more science advances, the more religion will decline. To what extent do you agree?
text:
The more science grows bigger, the less people care about religion, right? Well, I think that's only partly true. Sure, science has taught us a lot about the world—like how planets orbit and why lightning happens.  Back in the day, people thought these things were caused by gods or magic, but now we know better. 

So maybe it makes sense that some folks don't need religion anymore if they think science explains everything. But I still think religion is important for lots of reasons. First off, science doesn't really tell us what life is all about, you know? Like, why are we here? What happens after we die? These are big questions that religion tries to answer. 

Plus, religion can be a good thing for people because it gives them hope and comfort. Think about it: when things are tough, lots of people turn to their faith for strength. Religion also brings people together. Churches, mosques, temples—they all create communities where people can connect and support each other.  And don't forget, religion has a big history! Look at all those amazing cathedrals and artwork—that's all thanks to religion.

Some people say science and religion are totally opposite, but I think they can actually work together. Science helps us understand the "how" of things, while religion helps us understand the "why."  It's like a team!


In conclusion, even though science is awesome and keeps changing our world, I don't think it will ever completely replace religion. People still need faith, community, and answers to life's big questions.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Should we welcome or resist the idea of robots replacing human beings in the workplace?
text:
Should we welcome or resist the idea of robots taking over our jobs? That's a big question with no easy answer.  Some people say that robots are going to take all our jobs and leave us with nothing to do. Other people say that robots are going to create new jobs and make our lives better. I think we should welcome robots into the workplace, because they can do lots of things better than humans.

First of all, robots don't get tired or need breaks. They can work 24/7 without complaining. This means that companies can produce more stuff and sell it for cheaper prices.  Think about a factory making cars.  Robots can weld the metal parts together much faster and more accurately than humans. That means we can get more cars made, which is good for the economy.

Second, robots are really good at doing dangerous jobs.  Like if you think about firefighters going into burning buildings, it's super risky. Robots could be sent in to fight the fire and rescue people, keeping humans safe. Or imagine working in a mine, where there's a lot of chance of collapse. Robots could work down there, mining the resources without putting anyone at risk.

Third, robots are getting smarter all the time.  They can learn new things and do more complicated tasks. Soon, robots might be able to do things that we humans can't even imagine. They could be doctors, teachers, or even artists! 

Of course, some people are worried about robots taking over our jobs. But I think that's just a fear of the unknown.  Whenever new technology comes along, there are always some people who are afraid of it. But in the end, technology usually makes our lives better.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Should people be allowed to have children by artificial means?
text:
Should people be allowed to have children by artificial means? This is a big question, and there are many different sides to it.  On one hand, these new technologies can help people who would otherwise be unable to have children. It's really sad when couples can't have a family together because of medical problems. But on the other hand, there are some serious ethical concerns about creating life in a lab.

One big issue is what to do with unused embryos. When they make babies in a lab, sometimes there are extra embryos that aren't used. What happens to them? Some people say they should be destroyed, while others say they should be given to other couples who want children. It's a really tough decision, and there's no easy answer.

Another problem is that these technologies can be used to "design" babies. People might want to choose the sex of their baby, or even pick traits like intelligence or athletic ability. This could lead to a society where people are valued based on their genetic makeup, which is really unfair. 

Also, there are health risks associated with artificial reproduction. Sometimes, the process can be dangerous for the mother or the baby. We need to make sure that these technologies are safe before we start using them widely.


Some people say that it's everyone's right to choose whether or not to have children, and that artificial reproduction is just another way to exercise that right.  But I think we need to be very careful about this technology. It has the potential to change our world in profound ways, and we need to make sure that those changes are for the better.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Do you agree that we cannot trust the media?
text:
Do you agree that we cannot trust the media? This is a big question, and I think it's something everyone should think about.  Media is everywhere, on TV, in newspapers, even our phones! It tells us what's happening in the world, but can we really believe everything we see and hear?

Some people say yes, the media is trustworthy. They say journalists are ethical and want to tell the truth. But I think there are too many reasons why we should be skeptical. For example, have you ever seen a news story that just seemed too good to be true? Or maybe one that felt biased towards a certain person or group? That's because sometimes the media has an agenda, and they might twist the facts to fit their narrative.

Also, think about all the different kinds of media there is. You have your big news corporations, but then you have blogs, social media, even YouTube channels claiming to be "news."  It's hard to know who to believe anymore! And with so much fake news out there, it's easy to get caught up in something that isn't real.

Remember the story about Hillary Clinton and the pizza place? That was totally made up, but people believed it and even acted on it!  That's how dangerous fake news can be. 

The media used to be more trustworthy, I think. Back in the day, there were fewer outlets, and reporters had to do more fact-checking. Now, everything moves so fast, and it's hard to keep up. People just want to share things online, without thinking about whether they're true or not.

So, what can we do? Well, I think it's important to be critical of what you see and hear in the media. Don't just believe everything you read! Check your sources, look for different perspectives, and be aware of potential biases.

author: Chirin Soh
title: “The Internet makes it more difficult for governments to govern today.” How far do you agree with this statement?
text:
The internet make it more dificult for goverments to rule today? That's what people say, and I think there is some truth too it.

First off, the internet is a big place for bad guys to hide. They can do things like steal peoples information or money, and its really hard to catch them because they are always changing locations and using fake names. Like, remember that time Sony got hacked? It was a mess! All their movies and games were leaked online, and it cost them millions of dollars. See? The internet is a dangerous place for goverments.

Also, the internet is full of fake news. People can make up stories and spread them all over the world in seconds. This can make it hard for people to know what's true and what's not. Its like that time my friend told me his uncle was a secret agent, but I knew he was lying because he never wore a suit. Fake news is just as bad as that! It can make people angry and confused, and that's not good for goverments.

And then there's the whole issue of people saying what they want online. Like, on Twitter everyone can say whatever they think, even if its rude or mean. This makes it hard for goverments to control the message and keep people happy. Its like a classroom where no one listens to the teacher! Goverments need to be able to control the flow of information, but the internet makes that really difficult.

But I guess the internet also has some good points. Like, it can help goverments share information with people more quickly and easily. And it can also make it easier for people to vote. But overall, I think the bad things about the internet outweigh the good things when it comes to goverment. Its like a double-edged sword, you know?

author: Chirin Soh
title: How far has new media changed our way of life?
text:
New media has totally changed how we live our lives. Like, everyone uses the internet now, and it's super different from before.  Newspapers are dying 'cause nobody reads them anymore, and everybody is always on their phone.  It's like, the world is totally connected now, which is both good and bad.

One of the biggest things new media has done is make it easier to start businesses. You can create apps and sell stuff online without needing a store or anything. It's made it possible for people to be entrepreneurs even if they don't have a lot of money. Like, that guy who made Snapchat got super rich when he was still in college!

New media has also changed how we work. Lots of people are now "digital nomads" which means they just travel around and work on their laptops. It's like, freedom to live your life the way you want, but it can also be hard to find a place to focus sometimes.

Social media is another huge thing that has come from new media. It lets people share their thoughts and connect with each other all over the world.  It's good for raising awareness about important issues too, like that ALS ice bucket challenge everyone did a while back. People used it to raise money and awareness for a really serious disease. But sometimes social media can be bad too. There are so many fake news stories online, and it can be hard to know what to believe. It's also easy to get addicted to social media and spend too much time on it, which can make you feel lonely and isolated even though you're connected to lots of people online.

Overall, new media is a powerful tool that has changed our lives in many ways.  It has both good and bad sides, so it's important to use it wisely. We need to find ways to protect ourselves from the negative effects of new media while still taking advantage of its many benefits.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Artificial intelligence creates more problems than benefits. Discuss
text:
Artificial intelligence is groweing so fast its scaring people. Like with self-driving cars and robots painting pictures. It's crazy! Some people think AI will take over the world, wich would be bad cuz we like being in charge. But I don't think that will happen. AI can do lots of good stuff, like making work faster and solving big problems.

AI is really good at looking at lots of information super fast. It can help companies save money and make better decisions. For example, chatbots on websites can answer questions and help customers without needing a real person. AI can also be used to predict what people will buy, which helps companies make more stuff that people want.

AI can also help with problems like pollution. There are robots that sort trash and recycle things much faster than humans can. They're helping to keep our planet clean!

AI is even being used in medicine to help doctors diagnose diseases and develop new treatments. It can look at X-rays and other scans to find things that humans might miss, which could save lives. 

Of course, there are some risks with AI too. If it falls into the wrong hands, it could be used for bad things like making weapons or spreading fake news. We need to make sure that AI is used responsibly and ethically.


But overall, I think the benefits of AI outweigh the risks. It has the potential to make our lives better in so many ways.  

Score: 28/50

author: Wen Ying
title: In the light of increasing security threats, should countries still embrace the notion of a borderless world?
text:
A borderless world is like a dream come true for some people. They say that when countries are open to each other, it's good for trade and sharing ideas. Like, imagine you can get anything from anywhere in the world! But lately, there's been a lot of talk about how dangerous this idea is getting. With so many people moving around, bad stuff like terrorism can happen easier.

Some people think that letting everyone in is just asking for trouble. They say that different cultures don't always get along, and that immigrants could bring bad ideas or even violence with them. For example, didn't they have a big bombing in London once because of some foreign guy? See, it's dangerous!

But other people say that we need to work together to fight these problems. They think that if countries share information and help each other out, we can make the world safer. Like, imagine if all the countries teamed up to stop terrorists. Wouldn't that be amazing?

Plus, a borderless world could be really good for business. If companies can sell their stuff anywhere in the world, they'll make more money. And if people can travel freely, it's easier to start new businesses and find jobs. It's like a win-win situation!

Of course, there are risks. But I think the benefits of a borderless world outweigh the dangers. We just need to be smart about it and work together to make sure that everyone is safe.

author: Wen Ying
title: How has technology impacted health in today’s world?
text:
Technology has changed how we live, and it's impacted our health too. Like, everyone uses phones and computers now, so we're always online. This is bad 'cause it makes us less active and more likely to be overweight. We order food all the time instead of cooking, and we just sit around playing games or watching videos. It's not good for our bodies!

But technology also has some good things about it. Doctors can use fancy machines to see inside our bodies and find problems. They can also talk to other doctors online to get advice on how to treat us. This helps people get better faster and live longer. Plus, there are apps that can track our steps and remind us to exercise.

Technology is also helping scientists learn more about diseases. They can use computers to simulate how drugs work in the body before they even test them on humans. This saves time and money, and it could lead to new cures for diseases like cancer. 

So, technology has both good and bad effects on our health. It's important to be aware of both sides so we can make healthy choices. Like, we should still go outside and play, even if it means putting down our phones sometimes!

author: Chirin Soh
title: To what extent is education still the key to a nation’s success.
text:
all education systams are importent for nation success becaus it promots social cohesion and develops the economy.  Education is a big investement but sometims its got flaws, for example,  in singapre  the PSLE is to stresful for student.   

The biggest problem with education today is that its not always keeping up with times. Jobs are changing fast becuase of techonology. In five years half of all jobs will be gone! This means people need to keep learning new things or they will be left behind.  Germany and Switerland  are good example becasue they have vocational training that teachs people skilles they need for real jobes. But even if you learn new skilles, it is important to also be a global citizen. This means understanding different cultures and working with people from all over the world.   Education can help us do this by teaching about different cultures and giving us oportunities to meet people from other places. 

Another big problem with education is that it not always fair. Some students have more access to good schools and teachers than others. This means that some people start out with a big advantage, which is not fair.  We need to make sure that all students have the same opportunities to succeed, no matter where they come from or what their background is. 

Education also helps us to be better citizens. It teaches us about our rights and responsibilities, and it gives us the skills we need to participate in democracy. Education can help us to solve problems and make the world a better place. For example, education has helped to reduce poverty and improve health around the world.

author: Chirin Soh
title: To what extent has tourism has tourism had a negative impact on the environment.
text:
Tourism has had a big impact on the world, but mostly bad. Like, think about all the plastic bottles and trash tourists leave behind. And planes! They put so much pollutetion in the air that it's making the planet warmer.

It's like when you go to the beach and there are way too many people. It gets crowded, dirty, and nobody can enjoy it anymore. That's what's happening to a lot of places because of tourism.

Take for example, Mount Everest. People just throw their trash everywhere up there! It's supposed to be this amazing natural wonder, but now it's like a giant garbage dump. Sad! 

And coral reefs? Those are dying because tourists break them when they swim or snorkel. And the water gets polluted from all the boats and stuff.

Even places that try to be eco-friendly can have problems. Like, there was this one time I went to a "green" resort in Bali, but they were using way too much water. It made me think, maybe green isn't always as green as it seems.

But there are some good things happening too! Some people are starting to travel more responsibly and support businesses that care about the environment. And some countries are trying to limit the number of tourists who visit certain places. 

So, yeah, tourism can be bad for the planet, but we're not all doomed yet. If we all do our part, maybe we can make things better.

author: Chirin Soh
title: To what extent can the regulation of scientific or technological developments be justified.
text:
To what extent can the regulation of scientific or technological developments be justified? This is a big question, right? Like, science is super cool and it can help us solve problems, but sometimes it can also be dangerous. 

We have to think about who makes the rules about science. Is it the scientists themselves? The government? Big companies? It's complicated!  Sometimes, people in charge just want to make money, not think about what's best for everyone. Like, remember that time those pharmaceutical companies were charging way too much for medicine? That's why we need rules to make sure science is used for good, not just profit.

Think about AI. It's getting smarter every day, which is awesome, but also kinda scary. What if AI robots take over the world? Or what if they make fake videos that trick people? We need to be careful! We need laws about AI before it gets out of control. 

And don't forget about things like genetically modified food.  Some people say it's great because it can grow more food, but others worry about the long-term effects. It's important to have rules about these things to make sure they are safe for us and the planet.


It's a tough balance, right? We want science to advance and help us, but we also need to protect ourselves from the bad stuff. Maybe the best way is to have lots of people talking about it – scientists, politicians, regular people like you and me.

author: Chirin Soh
title: The global health threat is the most serious problem facing the world today. Do you agree?
text:
The global health threat is the biggest problem facing the world today.  It's way more important then stuff like poverty or war because everyone gets sick, even if you rich.

Diseases can spread super fast now that people travel all over the place. Remember that bird flu? That was scary! And the H1N1 virus in 2009, lots of people died from that. If a really bad disease started today, it could kill millions of people before anyone even knew what hit them.

We have doctors and medicine to help, but sometimes it's not enough.  Antibiotics don't always work anymore because bacteria are getting stronger. And some people just don't believe in vaccines, which is really dumb! They think they cause autism, but that's just a lie. 

The poor get sick the most because they don't have good healthcare or clean water. It's not fair. Everyone deserves to be healthy, no matter where they live or how much money they have.  We need to spend more money on hospitals and doctors, especially in Africa and Asia. Those places are really struggling.

Global health is a big problem, but we can fix it if we work together. We need to listen to scientists, get vaccinated, wash our hands, and be kind to each other.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Should medical science always seek to prolong life?
text:
Should medical science always seek to prolong life?

This is a big question that people have been thinking about for ages. Some say yes, because it's natural to want to live longer and healthier lives. Other say no, because there are other important things to focus on, like making sure everyone has enough food and water.  I think its important to look at both sides before making a decision. 

One problem with always trying to prolong life is that it can hurt the quality of life. When people get really old, they might not be able to do the things they used to enjoy. For example, my grandma had Alzheimer's and she couldn't remember who her family was anymore. It was really sad.

Also, it costs a lot of money to keep people alive for longer.  We could use that money to help people who are sick or poor instead. Think about all the kids in Africa who don't have enough food to eat! 

Another thing to consider is that it's not always clear if prolonging life is ethical. What happens if someone wants to die but doctors keep them alive? Is that really fair to them?

There are some good things about medical science trying to help people live longer, like finding cures for diseases. But I think we need to be careful not to get too carried away. It's important to remember that life is more than just how long it lasts.

We should focus on making sure people have good lives, even if they don't live forever.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Is technology the solution to the problem of global poverty?
text:
Technology can solve world poverty? That's what everyone says. Technology is amazing! It makes cars drive themselves and babies look better! Scientists are making medicines that make people live longer, and companies are inventing new apps all the time. This means technology can fix all our problems, like global poverty which affects billions of people around the world.

Lots of people in countries like India, Bangladesh, Niger, Liberia, are stuck in a cycle of poverty. It's like a trap they can't get out of because their families are poor and they don't have opportunities. But technology can help them escape!  It can give them jobs, education, and access to healthcare.

For example, there are now apps that teach people how to farm better, so they can grow more food and sell it for money. There are also apps that connect people with doctors, even if they live in remote areas. Technology can even help people get loans to start businesses.

But hold on!  Not everyone has access to technology. Some people can't afford phones or computers, and some places don't have internet access. This is a big problem because it means that technology isn't helping everyone equally. 

Plus, some companies might use technology to exploit workers. Like those Uber drivers who are forced to work long hours for low pay. That doesn't sound very fair!


In the end, technology has the potential to solve global poverty. But we need to make sure that it's used fairly and that everyone has access to its benefits. We also need to be careful about the downsides of technology, like worker exploitation. It's a complicated issue, but one that's worth working on!

author: Chirin Soh
title: Discuss the claim that resolving climate change is impossible today.
text:
Climate change is a big problem that lotsa people are talkin about. It's gettin hotter and hotter everywhere, and the ice caps are meltin faster than ever before. The news is always showin pictures of floods and fires, and it's scary to think about what will happen if we don't do somethin about it.

Some people say that it's impossible to fix climate change. They say that we've already done too much damage, and that there's no way to turn things around. But I think that's just a excuse for not doin anything. We need to keep tryin, even if it seems like a long shot. 

Governments all over the world are startin to take climate change seriously. They're makin laws to reduce pollution and invest in renewable energy.  Companies are also gettin on board, with many promisin to be more sustainable.

We can all do our part too, even if it seems like just a little thing. We can ride bikes instead of cars, turn off the lights when we leave a room, and recycle everything we can. If everyone does their part, it will make a big difference. 

We need to remember that our planet is our home. It's the only one we got, so we need to take care of it. We have a responsibility to future generations to leave them a healthy and livable world.

author: Chirin Soh
title: Consumerism is a curse on the environment. Discuss.
text:
Consumerism is bad for the planet, like really bad! Its everywhere you look. People are always buying new stuff they don't need, and that's making the Earth sick. 

Think about it: all those factories making clothes and toys and gadgets, they pollute the air and water. And all those cars people drive to go shopping? They spew out even more pollution! Plus, when we throw stuff away, it ends up in landfills, which take forever to break down. It's a mess!

Take plastic, for example. People use it for everything – bags, bottles, straws – and it just sits around forever because it doesn't decompose. It ends up in the ocean, where animals get tangled in it or eat it, thinking it's food. Sad, right?

And what about deforestation? Companies cut down trees to make paper, furniture, and building materials. That destroys habitats for animals and plants, and it releases tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, which is what causes global warming. 

We need to change our ways! We should buy less stuff, reuse what we have, and recycle everything we can. We need to support companies that are eco-friendly and hold those who aren't accountable for their actions.  

It's not easy, but it's the only way to save our planet. Otherwise, future generations are going to inherit a world that's pretty messed up.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: Technology has alienated people instead of bringing them together. Discuss.
text:
Technology has made people more lonely then ever before. It's like everyone is glued to their screens and they forgot how to talk to each other!

Like, remember when you would actually go outside and play with your friends? Now everyone is just sitting at home playing video games or scrolling through social media. 

Its not even real conversation, its all just quick messages and emojis. You can't really get to know someone if you only talk to them online. Plus, everyone is always comparing themselves to other people on these apps, which makes them feel bad about themselves. It's like a competition for who has the most followers or likes.

And don't even get me started on dating apps. They are all about looks and superficial stuff.  People just swipe left or right based on a picture. Where is the real connection? 

Technology is supposed to bring people together, but it's doing the opposite. It's creating a society of loners who are afraid to interact with each other in real life.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: To lodge all power in one party and keep it there is to ensure bad government. Do you agree?
text:
To lodge all power in one party and keep it there is to ensure bad government. Do you agree?

That's a big question.  Lots of people think that having just one party in charge sounds good, like it would be faster and more efficient. They say things could get done quicker without all the arguing and backstabbing between different parties. For example, China is always moving fast on building stuff and making decisions, they don't have to waste time debating with other parties. But I think that's kinda scary because what happens when that one party makes a mistake? 

It seems like if everyone has the same ideas and nobody else can say "Hey, maybe that's not such a good idea", then things could go really wrong.  Like, imagine if there was only one type of food in the whole world, everyone would get sick of it eventually! Same thing with government, you need different opinions to make sure everything is fair and working for everyone. 

Plus, if all power is in one place, that means people could lose their voice. They might not have a chance to speak up about things that are important to them or even just complain when something isn't right. That wouldn't be very democratic now, would it?  It's like having a teacher who never listens to the students, eventually everyone gets bored and stops paying attention. 

History is full of examples where one party had too much power and things went bad. Like the Soviet Union, they tried to control everything and people suffered because of it. 


So yeah, I don't think it's a good idea to put all power in one party. It might seem easier at first, but in the long run, it's probably going to lead to problems. We need different parties with different ideas to make sure things stay balanced and fair.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: Can the media ever tell the truth?
text:
Can the Media Ever Tell the Truth?

The media is everywhere! Its on our phones, TV's and even in our schools. It tells us what to think about everything, from politics to pop culture. But can we really trust it? Some people say the media is just a bunch of liars, always trying to push their own agendas. Others say that there are good and bad parts of the media, and that sometimes it can be truthful. So who's right?

I think its true that the media can be biased. For example, I once saw a news report about a new video game that was totally unfair! The reporter said it was boring and lame, but my friends and I thought it was awesome! Maybe the reporter just didn't like the same kind of games as us.

Another problem with the media is that sometimes it makes up stories! I heard about this one time where a newspaper printed an article about a giant monster living in the ocean. It turned out to be a big hoax, and the newspaper had to apologize. That made me lose trust in them. 

But even though there are problems with the media, I still think it can sometimes tell the truth. For example, when there was that big earthquake last year, the news showed us real footage of the damage and talked to people who were affected by it. That seemed pretty honest to me.

I also think that having lots of different sources of information is important. If you only read one newspaper or watch one TV channel, you might not get the whole story. It's good to compare what different sources are saying and make up your own mind. 

In conclusion, the media can be both good and bad. It's important to be critical of what you read and watch and to get information from a variety of sources.

author: Stephanie Heng
title: Can national nuclear programmes ever be justified?
text:
Can national nuclear programmes ever be justified? 

Nuclear energy is super powerful, it comes from inside atoms and can make lots of electricity. But, people are always scared of it because of things like radiation and accidents.  Should countries have their own nuclear programs even if they're dangerous? I think yes, but it has to be done right.

Some people say that nuclear weapons are bad because they destroy everything. They point to Hiroshima and Nagasaki, where thousands of people died in the bombs. That was really sad, but we can't forget that nuclear weapons also keep countries safe.  Think about the Cold War - no one started a real war because both sides had nukes. It's scary, but it worked!  Even now, India and Pakistan are less likely to fight because they both have nukes. So, having nukes can actually prevent bad things from happening.

Also, nuclear energy is good for the environment. We use too much oil and gas, which pollute the planet. Nuclear power doesn't do that as much. Japan learned this after their earthquake - they closed all their nuclear plants and electricity got more expensive, AND pollution went up! So having nukes for power can be good for everyone.

But yeah, there are risks. Chernobyl was a disaster, and Fukushima too.  Those were really bad accidents because people didn't follow the rules. We need to make sure that never happens again. We need strong laws and people who know what they're doing. The IAEA helps with that - they keep an eye on everything.

So, are nuclear programs ever justified? I think so, but only if we do it safely and responsibly. It's a tough question, but we have to think about all the sides.

author: Skyler
title: ‘Prosperity is all that matters; everything else can take a back seat.’ Do you agree?
text:
Prosperity is all that matters; everything else can take a back seat. Do you agree?

The concept of prosperity has been debated by scholars and policymakers for centuries. While some argue that prosperity is the ultimate goal of human society, others contend that it is merely a means to an end. As I pondered this question, I couldn't help but think of my recent trip to the Grand Canyon. The majestic landscape, the vast expanse of the Colorado River, and the eerie silence of the desert landscape all converged to create an experience that was truly sublime. It was as if the universe had conspired to create a moment of pure joy, untainted by the mundane concerns of everyday life.

As I delved deeper into the canyon, I began to notice the intricate patterns of erosion that had shaped the rock over millions of years. The slow, relentless process of geological transformation was a testament to the power of time and the fragility of human existence. It was a humbling experience, one that forced me to reevaluate my own place in the grand scheme of things.

But what does this have to do with prosperity, you might ask? Well, as I reflected on my experience, I realized that true prosperity is not just about accumulating wealth or achieving economic growth. It's about living a life that is authentic, meaningful, and connected to the natural world. It's about recognizing the limits of human knowledge and the importance of preserving our planet for future generations.

In conclusion, while prosperity may be a necessary condition for human flourishing, it is by no means sufficient. We must recognize the importance of living in harmony with nature and cultivating a deeper sense of purpose and meaning in our lives. Only then can we truly say that prosperity is not just a means to an end, but an end in itself.

author: Skyler
title: Do you agree that freedom of speech should never be denied even though it can be abused?
text:
The freedom of speech is a fundamental right that has been debated by scholars and politicians for centuries.
